newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian stocks lock in solid gains by close.
newsitem.headline: Australian stocks lock in solid gains by close.

text.p: A buoyant Australian share market locked in solid gains by the close on Wednesday after Wall Street surged and local markets comfortably digested March quarter inflation figures.
The All Ordinaries index climbed 24.7 points to 2,472.3.

With a big rally in the Dow, stronger base metals prices and a consumer price index (CPI) that confirmed a low inflation environment, the market settled comfortably higher by noon and spent the rest of the day tethered to a narrow six point range.
"It looked solid all day after the States gave us the initial lead," said a dealer at a Sydney brokerage.
"CPI didn't cause much of a fuss. We finished off the highs but it was never going to hold it all."
Trade was strong with two-way business across the board the driving factor rather than interest in individual stocks.
"It has been a pretty quiet day, even though turnover was healthy. There hasn't been anything that has been too enthralling," said dealer Scott Healey of brokerage Wilson HTM.
Aluminium producer Comalco Ltd was one feature, up 4.4 percent to A$6.70 (US$5.23), after it forecast an improved 1997 result.

Macquarie Bank also caught the eye, leaping 5.5 percent to close at a record high A$9.60 as investors viewed the fees the investment bank was likely to earn from its role in the A$4.86 billion Loy Yang A power privatisation in Victoria.
West Australian regional Bankwest closed up one at A$2.53 after its full year net profit of A$94.5 million.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about eight to five, while about 28 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
